newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian MinFins firm after U.S. data.
newsitem.headline: Russian MinFins firm after U.S. data.

text.p: Russian MinFin bonds firmed on Tuesday, tracking firmer U.S. Treasuries after positive U.S. statistics in otherwise quiet trading, dealers said.
U.S. March durable goods orders fell 3.0 percent, the largest drop since August 1996. The consensus forecast was for durable goods orders to be unchanged overall.
The first quarter U.S. employment cost index (ECI) rose 0.6 percent, versus the forecast for an 0.9-percent gain. The ECI rose 0.8 percent in the previous report.
U.S. Treasury bond prices, which often set the tone for MinFins, rose sharply after the data, which dimmed expectations of another Fed interest rate hike in the near future.
Dealers said the fourth and sixth tranches gained the most.
"Prices started rising after data, following higher U.S. Treasuries. Statistics turned out to be positive for MinFins," an International Moscow Bank dealer said.

Mosbiznesbank dealer Pavel Navolokin said trading was otherwise calm over the day with Russian banks pushing up the 2003 maturity in early trading on speculative buying but the paper met resistance of Western banks at 60.25 level.
Further important U.S. data will be released this week, which will be closely watched for signs of inflationary pressures in the U.S. economy.
On Wednesday, gross domestic product for the first quarter is released. The April NAPM report comes on Thursday, and on Friday the all-important employment report for April will hit the market.
On May 20 the U.S. policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee meets and could raise U.S. interest rates.
